reasoning that the failure to extend the on-premises limitation to Section 302(a) would contravene the requirement that statutes are to be construed in such a way as to make the entire statute effective
indicating that neither Section 302(a) nor 302(b) applied where the alleged statutory employer did not control or occupy the premises where the injury occurred
"An entity's status as a 'statutory employer' results in liability for workers' compensation insurance and, coextensively, provides immunity to the statutory employer from common law tort liability."
"The McDonald test has been utilized over the years to determine whether an entity is a statutory employer under both the tort immunity section (203) and the insurer section (302(b))."
"A statutory employer is a master who is not a contractual or common-law one, but is made one by the Act."

"Where an owner contracts with another for work on his premises in furtherance of his regular business, the employment is an independent one, establishing the relation of contractee and contractor and not that of master and servant or statutory employer or employee----"
"A statutory employer is a master who is not a contractual or common-law one, but is made one by the Act."
